text: Hi! Could please anyone share his experience to whether confirm or not that the mobile phone - the personal device and personal information which are processed by the application and that is on the local storage of mobile device doesn't fall under law (country does not matter) about protection and storage of personal information?

<@U0RPUFPRU>: I’m not sure I understand the question, but if you’re talking about how different countries treat mobile privacy, it varies wildly and is changing all the time. In the U.S., a somewhat recent Supreme Court decision found that law enforcement needs a warrant to search a person’s phone, as if it were his or her home. In that case, there were two dumbphones involved. However, this issue comes up again and again and in different forms—look at Apple’s fight with the FBI for example. Sorry for a complicated answer. Anyone else want to weigh in? <@U04TK850N>? <@U0548MM6B>? <@U061HDV96>?
<@U0DMFJC0H>: thank you a lot! I will look at Apple’s fight with the FBI

Regarding police unlocking your phone - as far as I know in the US:
Fifth Amendment protects your rights to not unlock your phone via passcode when asked to and a precedent was set for that recently, but also apparently biometric unlock (fingerprint) doesn’t fall under that.
Now, in Europe, I _believe_ that the personal information that is on the local storage of the device and is processed inside application (but never uploaded) doesn’t fall under Data protection laws since it isn’t transmitted and is kept locally on the users device.
There are certain anti-terror provisions in the UK where failure to comply with requests to unlock a device can land you in prison

So you want to know if you are responsible to protect a user's data, on the phone locally, from malicious use? Or is that about analyzing that data locally to gain something from it? I'm pretty sure that if none of the personal information covered by those laws leaves the phone then you would be safe. But take that with a grain of salt, I''m not an expert. If the question is the former, then could I hold Microsoft responsible if I catch some Ransomware and lose my files?
Reminder: In 15 minutes, <@U0DM5TP6D> will be leading a DSM conversation on /p. <http://slashpolicy.com/>
<@U0DMFJC0H>: bummer that I couldn't be there :confused: Is it saved somewhere?
